description: From Middle English betaken, bitaken, in form equivalent to be- +‎ take, however, in sense from betæcen, betechen (“to beteach”). More at beteach.

verbs.description: betake (third-person singular simple present betakes, present participle betaking, simple past betook, past participle betaken)

description: From Middle English bitaken, equivalent to be- +‎ take. Cognate with Danish betage (“to take, deprive, cut off”), Swedish beta (“to take, deprive, cut off”).

verbs.description: betake (third-person singular simple present betakes, present participle betaking, simple past betook, past participle betaken)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To take over to; take across (to); deliver.
(transitive, obsolete) To seize; lay hold of; take. [from 15th c.]
examples: a rain-cloud [...] had betaken a dusky brown color, and about its lower verge a fringe of fine straight lines of rain was suggested [...].

entries.meaning: (reflexive, archaic) To take oneself to; go or move; repair; resort; have recourse. [from 17th c.]
examples: They betook themselves to treaty and submission.

entries.meaning: (reflexive, archaic) To commit to a specified action. [from 16th c.]
(transitive, archaic) To commend or entrust to; to commit to.
